body: I'm setting `druid.indexer.runner.pendingTasksRunnerNumThreads=1` for the overlord to ensure this does not occur.
Config was introduced in #2521 (0.9.1)
üëç
@drcrallen can you backport?
@drcrallen shall we move this to 0.9.2 given that #3184 works around it?
oops, move to 0.9.2, I mean.

@fjy this already is to 0.9.1  That leaves master with a default of 3.

As per https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/McGZdcnO0Ws/9gz8UxQDDAAJ we can either leave master as is and put a fix in before 0.9.2, or push this upstream and get to it at some other point.
@gianm https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/McGZdcnO0Ws/9gz8UxQDDAAJ
ah, thanks
@nishantmonu51 updated PR with changes, thanks for reviewing

@acslk looking good so far! Just had some minor comments about naming, docs, and formatting.

üëç
üëç  LGTM
üëç

@rajk-tetration, I haven't looked in detail yet, but I bet you'll also have to adjust `filterSegments` in TimeBoundaryQueryQueryToolChest (and add a test for the case where there is a filter).

For the test I see you had a comment like "no rows matched the filter--what is expected behavior in that case?". Probably the same as whatever an unfiltered timeBoundary would do if there were rows at all (I think that's returning an empty array, but double-check).
-0 from me as this change is renaming some variables that I personally do not feel need renaming. But if anyone else is +1 then go for it. Otherwise, @jianran, thanks anyway for the interest!
üëç

@rajk-tetration 

1.) I think the TimeBoundaryQueryRunnerFactory implementation is reasonable

2.) For the QueryRunnerTestHelper, the datasource isn't actually used if you call 

```
public static <T, QueryType extends Query<T>> List<QueryRunner<T>> makeQueryRunners(
      QueryRunnerFactory<T, QueryType> factory
  )
```

that function uses a hard-coded set of segments.

For testing, MultiSegmentSelectQueryTest may be a useful reference. 

The default `druid.sample.tsv` is problematic for testing this filtering behavior as you pointed out; MultiSegmentSelectQueryTest creates its own segments so you'll have control over the timestamps. 

The multi segment structure may also be useful for testing the `filterSegments` behavior that @gianm mentioned.

3) I think a  change needed to finalize is to implement/verify that the filtering works on multiple segments.
Given that this is the second regression introduced by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2521, would it make sense to have another review of that PR before we declare stable?
üëç
@kaijianding I looked at the core changes in IncrementalIndex today, seems good so far, will review the rest as well
@gianm oh, yes I think I have already done but wrote the name wrong. I just did this again correctly. Thank you.

üëç

@jon-wei can you add some docs also with an example doing filtering on a time column ? 
or are you planning to do it in a follow up PR?

@kaijianding 

How many iterations did you run? There seems to be a 5-6% slowdown for ingestion, which is significant. There is also a wide error range. Does running more iterations help reduce this error range? If there is actually a 5-6% slowdown in performance, I think it is worth investigating why the slowdown is occurring as ideally there should be no performance impact when rollup is turned on.
this is tricky. If I had to completely guess, I'd say the jersey servelet is puking because `io.druid.query.lookup.NamespaceLookupExtractorFactory$1` is in its own classloader

@nishantmonu51 I've added a section to the docs on filtering on __time
@xvrl what's fixed? are they needed for 0.9.1?

@redlion99 I believe this happens when you have a dimension field that is the empty string. Ideally that would work but it does not. Could you try working around it by adding `""` to `dimensionExclusions`?

I tested this on 0.9.1 and 0.9.0 and it seems to be a pre-existing problem (same exception in both versions).

@gianm https://github.com/druid-io/druid-console/commit/5d13133c98d1885243db6fe43ac63547d17864ed and https://github.com/druid-io/druid-console/commit/1f601c7f5800e8ba6715b1e628a7a542976ed2e8
Nothing critical, but nice to have.
üëç
can we move this to 0.9.2?
@fjy we've deployed and tested the changes on our end in production.
No filter takes dimensionSpec, they all take dimension + extractionFn (including SearchQueryDimFilter). the rationale is: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3082#issuecomment-224397267

üëç 

I'm OK with 0.9.1 if you can do a backport @xvrl
@gianm thanks, I went blind for some reason, and didn't see the `extractionFn` in the search filter. Will close this out.
Closing in favor of #3028
@himanshug I think you fixed, this do you mind adding a reference to your PR here?
That was #1472
this was fixed @fjy since you were pushing for this, can you mentioned the PR that fixes this in the comments?
That was #2271
caffeine cache solves this in #3028 (See https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Efficiency for details)
If you are having trouble deploying Druid I would suggest asking for advice in the Druid user forum https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-user

here is the latest benchmark after running with more iterations on a more powerful machine and with slightly code modification, @fjy

For those interested, a production-ready spark indexer is available for testing in https://github.com/metamx/druid-spark-batch
We have been using it in production for several months now. It lacks some of the features and configuration options of the hadoop indexer, but otherwise perfectly capable to handle large-scale tasks.
I believe this is fixed for HDFS by #1702, not sure about S3. @himanshug ?

What happens if start() is called, but before it finishes the jvm is shutdown and stop() is called?
@drcrallen In that case this should fire: `Preconditions.checkState(started, "not started");` (setting started is the last thing start does)

I guess what you're asking though is, is that a good thing or a bad thing?

Maybe?
@drcrallen let me know if you think we need to do something in addition to / instead of the started precondition

@gianm then it will fail to shutdown the executor service, and the consumer will be running for an arbitrary length of time until the jvm simply halts. That seems like it could have unintended consequences. I suggest having some sort of synchronization on the start/stop methods such that when stop finishes, it has pretty good guarantees on what the state of the consumer is.
@drcrallen sounds good, synchronized the start and stop logic
@xvrl Can we get traces from Druid? It would be interesting to see efficiencies. Chatted about this briefly with @drcrallen (we need a log of key hashes to run through the simulator)

@ben-manes let me see what I can do. I think our best bet is to turn off local cache on one node and turn on request logging on one of our memcached instances. That should give us equivalent traces without impacting performance too much.
@ben-manes how much data would you need?
üëç

That makes sense. It could cause some skew since the memcached is shared and sharded by key, but hopefully pretty close regardless. The other option is to append to an async logger and assuming that it doesn't drop messages too frequently.

The ARC traces are the best I have so far, and they are each around 50 - 100mb gzip'd. The paper reports that they are 1-6 hours or a few days, I guess depending on how active the cache is for that product. Given @drcrallen's description of the concurrency challenges I suspect an hour is plenty if you have such high volumes. I would `xz` compresses for a much smaller file.

I suspect your workloads have a lot of scans, so it will be interesting to see where the different policies line up. It should also provide some insight of when the caches top out and adding more memory doesn't improve things.

I think this is a good start. If this class develops more, I suggest moving towards more discrete states and ensuring things like: the handler thread can't try to take from the queue until the start method has finished.

But I think this improves the stateful ness of the supervisor.

In the future, very thorough concurrency testing would be nice.  but üëç as is for a bug fix

General note that `numLoadingThreads` and `numBootstrapThreads` do two different things. 

It looks like `numLoadingThreads` is not handled properly. That config is used to create the executor for the PathChildrenCache, which explicitly states: `ExecutorService to use for the PathChildrenCache's background thread. This service should be single threaded, otherwise the cache may see inconsistent results.`

As such `numLoadingThreads` should always be the default of 1.
:+1:  it should work fine. While doing #1702 I probably dint realize it was broken for s3 as well. thanks.
